We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with vomiting of blood and a history of alcoholic cirrhosis, which suggests that he has bleeding esophageal varices. The best initial management for this patient is combined vasoactive and endoscopic therapy to stop the bleeding and prevent rebleeding. Non-selective beta-blockers can be used for primary prophylaxis of bleeding esophageal varices but are not appropriate for acute bleeding. Balloon tamponade and TIPS are options for refractory bleeding or as a bridge to more definitive therapy but are not appropriate as initial management.
